messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] gold inlay question
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, I had the same thought.  I don t see why o-suriage would be more challenging to fit than a newly made sword.  But, I ve never made a habaki. I had a
messages.messageBody:
Alan,
I had the same thought. I don't see why o-suriage would be more challenging to fit than a newly made sword. But, I've never made a habaki.

I had a sword with an old-looking, somewhat crude two piece plain copper habaki. It was on a sword that was shortened a few cm. It served its purpose, but it was far from precision work.
Jim



Jim,
If anything it would be easier to fit a habaki to an o-suriage blade than an
ubu one as the latter might have a nakago that is greatly thicker than the
blade itself.

I have a two piece habaki that is solid gold/silver covered with sheet gold,
it looks very old and is of crude manufacture compared with similar good
quality late Edo habaki which fit together almost like clockwork. I think it
was probably made by a country maker, any thoughts on this would be welcome.
Alan


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Jim,
If anything it would be easier to fit a habaki to an o-suriage blade than an

I have a two piece habaki that is solid gold/silver covered with sheet gold,

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, August 19, 2003 1:37 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] gold inlay question


: Matt,
: Tanobe-san was referring to Honami "attribution mei" rather than cutting
tests. I don't know whether cutting test inscriptions were initially filed
flush with the surface of the nakago or not. If the inlay was raised at all
there won't be a reference point. Also, an old but false cutting test or
attribution would presumably have the same "depth" as a correct one of the
same age. I wouldn't take it as a certain test of the validity of an inlaid
inscription.
:
: I heard another tidbit about Umetada habaki once that I haven't been able
to verify. Their habaki are certainly of very high quality and the
construction and finish are distinctive, but I was told that the Umetada
were exceptionally good at fitting habaki to o-suriage swords. I'm not sure
what to make of that... anyone have any ideas? I've certainly seen Umetada
habaki on ubu tanto, so their type is not strictly developed for the nakago
of shortened blades.
:
: Jim
:
:
:
: Wow Jim, these are exactly the pearls I like to hear. Incredible ! When
: you think about it, it makes complete sense, but I doubt anyone would
: ever take the trouble to figure something like that out over here.
:
: Now, we can tell the fake cutting tests from the genuine ones with a
: simple swoop. Very much appreciated, this info is, thanks Jim !
:
: - Matt

> to verify. Their habaki are certainly of very high quality and the
> construction and finish are distinctive, but I was told that the Umetada were
> exceptionally good at fitting habaki to o-suriage swords. I'm not sure what to make
> of that... anyone have any ideas? I've certainly seen Umetada habaki on ubu
> tanto, so their type is not strictly developed for the nakago of shortened
> blades.
>
> Jim
>

Jim und all,
Are the Umetada habaki signed ? If not, what's the distinctive features that
point to the attribuion of Umetada besides high quality ?
Thanks,
Milt

messages.subject: Re: gold inlay question
messages.msgSnippet: ... able to verify.  Their habaki are certainly of very high quality and the construction and finish are distinctive, Jim - What is distinctive about Umetada
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>

> I heard another tidbit about Umetada habaki once that I haven't been
able to verify. Their habaki are certainly of very high quality and
the construction and finish are distinctive,

Jim -

What is distinctive about Umetada habaki? I wouldn't know one
if I tripped over it. Any pics avaiable?

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] gold inlay question
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Tanobe-san was referring to Honami attribution mei rather than cutting tests.  I don t know whether cutting test inscriptions were initially filed
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
Tanobe-san was referring to Honami "attribution mei" rather than cutting tests. I don't know whether cutting test inscriptions were initially filed flush with the surface of the nakago or not. If the inlay was raised at all there won't be a reference point. Also, an old but false cutting test or attribution would presumably have the same "depth" as a correct one of the same age. I wouldn't take it as a certain test of the validity of an inlaid inscription.

I heard another tidbit about Umetada habaki once that I haven't been able to verify. Their habaki are certainly of very high quality and the construction and finish are distinctive, but I was told that the Umetada were exceptionally good at fitting habaki to o-suriage swords. I'm not sure what to make of that... anyone have any ideas? I've certainly seen Umetada habaki on ubu tanto, so their type is not strictly developed for the nakago of shortened blades.

Jim



Wow Jim, these are exactly the pearls I like to hear. Incredible ! When
you think about it, it makes complete sense, but I doubt anyone would
ever take the trouble to figure something like that out over here.

Now, we can tell the fake cutting tests from the genuine ones with a
simple swoop. Very much appreciated, this info is, thanks Jim !

- Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:
Wow Jim, these are exactly the pearls I like to hear. Incredible ! When
you think about it, it makes complete sense, but I doubt anyone would
ever take the trouble to figure something like that out over here.

Now, we can tell the fake cutting tests from the genuine ones with a
simple swoop. Very much appreciated, this info is, thanks Jim !

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: maandag 18 augustus 2003 22:31
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] gold inlay question


Matt,
Not exactly my field, but I believe that they were done by kinko. The
Umetada did some kinzogan-mei for the Honami. I seem to recall another
specific group that worked for the Honami but I don't remember who it
was. I'm sure that a variety of kinko inlaid kinzogan-mei and cutting
tests. Maybe someone else on the list knows more.

If I understood correctly, during one of his lectures at the Tampa show
this year Tanobe-san mentioned that original Honami kinzogan-mei should
be slightly lower than the surface of the nakago. He explained that as
the nakago rusts over the years the volume of the resulting iron oxide
is greater than that of the iron it developed from. So the gold inlay
stays at the level of the original filed surface, but the surrounding
iron "grows thicker" as it rusts. I haven't checked it out for myself,
though. Anyone have a good Honami kinzogan-mei handy to check?

Jim



Gang, I was looking at a sword with a cutting test inscription inlayed
in gold today. Part of it had fallen out.

Now I understand the the inscriptions were done (composed) by the
Honami
family, but who actually inlayed the inscription in gold and how was
this done ?

Did a smith do this, or a kinko artist perhaps ? Or did they do it
themselves ?

- Matt
